node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.
What’s a career crush? It’s a platonic crush you develop on someone who has a really cool job and is doing really cool things. In this episode, I interviewed one of my career crushes, Dave Jorgenson (@dave.jorgenson), to get to the bottom of what it’s like to be a full-time TikTok producer.

Dave's entire job is to make TikToks for the @washingtonpost. And his videos hit the mark — they're consistently informative, funny, and on-trend. I've always wondered: How does he do it? How does he continue to make hilarious, news-centered videos every day? What is it like to make TikToks for a living?

I sat down with Dave to chat with him about his journey from interning at The Colbert Report, to making YouTube videos, to becoming the newspaper-hat-wearing TikToker. We discussed his creative process, how he turned his job into one he loves, and how he helped The Washington Post’s TikTok reach almost one million followers.

I’m also really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend! Thanks for watching 🤗

node.title: What It’s Like to Make TikToks for a Living

node.text:
Women are often told that if they can fix their imposter syndrome, they'd be more successful in their careers. But is it really a lack of confidence holding them back — or is it systemic bias?

Today we spoke with @jodiannburey and @rtulshyan, HBR authors working to debunk the idea that imposter syndrome is a problem that's on individuals to solve. They argue that the “diagnosis” of imposter syndrome is problematic because it fails to acknowledge the historical and cultural contexts that affect the way women are treated — especially women of color.

Watch the full live conversation with HBR editor @ramsey.online here and add any questions you have about the topic in the comments.

Find the articles on HBR.org:

"Stop Telling Women They Have Imposter Syndrome"

"End Imposter Syndrome in Your Workplace"

node.text:
Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “How to Get Out of a Creative Rut,” I come face-to-face with my biggest demon: feeling mentally blocked. Some days I feel extremely inspired and productive; then there are others when I’m convinced I have no more ideas left in my brain. Nada. Nothing. Nope.

To help, I confessed my anxieties to entrepreneur @sonjarasula, who reassured me that creative ruts happen to everyone and they are completely normal (and expected). She offered ideas on how to reset ourselves to escape the typical creative rut, and strategies to prevent a bigger creative crisis down the line.
I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend.

node.title: How to Get Out of a Creative Rut

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

There are plenty of challenges when it comes to trusting colleagues, especially in a world with hybrid offices and remote teams. Do people trust me? How can I make sure there’s trust on my team? And what can I do if trust is broken?

In this episode, “How to Build — and Repair — Trust at Work,” @LSU_slhrd professor Tyree Mitchell and I explore the building blocks of trust, how to embed it in a work culture, and what to do when it breaks down.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: How to Build — and Repair — Trust at Work

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend. In this episode, I’m looking for a better way to give difficult feedback.

Giving feedback can feel like a real struggle. The last thing I want to do is hurt someone's feelings, and in the spirit of “not rocking the boat,”  I sometimes put off giving necessary feedback, which inevitably makes things worse (and more awkward) over time. Other times, I might be motivated to speak up, but my words inadvertently come off the wrong way and put the other person in a hardened defensive mode.

With the help of author Liane Davey (@lianedavey), I learn the key four steps of delivering constructive, useful feedback. It all makes sense when Liane explains that feedback isn’t really about the other person — it’s about YOU! (Trust me, just watch.)

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: How to Give Feedback — Especially When You’re Dreading It

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine, host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “You Need Tough Feedback — Here's How to Get It,” I investigate the best way to get quality feedback so I can improve and grow in my role. But there are plenty of challenges. Sometimes feedback can feel shallow and vague (“Good job!”). Other times I find myself blindsided by unexpected criticism. And if I get feedback that’s tough to swallow, what’s the best way to respond?

With the help of career coach Octavia Goredema (@octaviagoredema), I learn how to best prepare for feedback, strategies for finding time and space for listening and reflection, and ways to build the foundation for ongoing constructive dialogue.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: You Need Tough Feedback — Here’s How to Get It

node.text:
👋Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

For over a year, I’ve been glued to video calls and accustomed to being “camera-ready” at all hours of the day. But I wonder: Have expectations changed at all? What is now acceptable in our Zoom-fatigued lives and what still looks…weird? 

In this episode, “Does Virtual Presence Still Matter at Work?” I talked with professional presence coach Rachel Cossar (@rachelonpointe) about what we’ve learned about physicality and technology this past year. I also got tips on how to exude presence if my camera isn’t on during a meeting and received a final verdict on virtual backgrounds.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: Does Virtual Presence Still Matter at Work

node.text:
👋Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “How to Make a Presentation Deck That Doesn't Stink,” I come to terms with my fear that my slide decks are boring, confusing, ugly, or all of the above. At the end of the day, how do I transform them into a compelling show?

With the help of design professor Dan Zedek (@danzedek), I learned some tips for turning a slide deck into a good story, plus some other guidelines to further engage my audience. His advice will definitely change the way I approach my next presentation!

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @hbrascend ✌️

node.title: How to Make a Presentation Deck that Doesn’t Stink

node.text:
👋Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work.”

In this episode, “How to Make Friends at Work,” I wrestle with one of the biggest predictors of burnout: loneliness. How can you become less lonely at work? The easy answer is to “make friends.” But how does that happen? And how do you make it not feel super weird?

With the help of journalist Jennifer Moss (@jleighmoss), author of “The Burnout Epidemic,” I learned more about the real risks of loneliness and embarked on a mission to forge a new friendship with a colleague.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel.✌️

node.title: How to Be Less Lonely at Work

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work.”

I struggle with speaking up and sharing my ideas in meetings (all virtual these days). Why does it feel so hard? Is there a way to overcome the awkwardness and anxiety of piping up? In this episode, “How to Speak Up in Meetings,” speaker and trainer Justin Hale (@oneproductiveminute) teaches me a framework I can practice and apply to upcoming meetings.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss Season 2 of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel.

✌️

node.title: How to Speak Up in Meetings

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work.”

In this episode, “What Does ‘Just Be Yourself’ Really Look Like at Work?,” I’m curious about what being your authentic self really means. Why should organizations prioritize a culture that celebrates authenticity — and what are the real risks if they don’t? In a conversation with Madison Butler (@corprteunicorn), VP of People + Impact at GRAV, we unpack what it means to feel like a human at work.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss Season 2 of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel.
✌️

node.title: What Does “Just Be Yourself” Really Look Like at Work?,

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work.”

In this episode, “How to Be More Productive,” I dive into the wild world of productivity methods and techniques. Do they really work — and how? To answer this question, I test drive #pomodorotechnique, @focusmate, and @caveday, and I probe what productivity really means with author Chris Bailey (@chrisbaileyauth).

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss the upcoming Season 2 premiere of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel.
✌️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 26, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says '4 Strategies for Building Hybrid Workplace that Works Focus on equity, engagement, and ease.'.

node.text:
Deciding who works from the office and how often is complex. If done poorly, hybrid arrangements can threaten culture, collaboration, and innovation. Conversely, a well-executed hybrid workplace can be a magnet that brings people together and helps us work better than ever before.

Architects and office-furniture designers serving the world’s largest organizations recommend leaders think through four design approaches as they consider hybrid strategy:

1.	Braiding the digital and physical experience. Integrate physical spaces and technology with three key concepts in mind: equity, engagement, and ease.

2.	Flipping enclosed and open spaces. Meetings will happen more often in open spaces with movable boundaries, so they need as much flexibility as possible — and individual focus work will happen in enclosed spaces like pods or small enclaves, so they need as much privacy as people are used to when they WFH.

3.	Shifting from fixed to fluid. The hybrid future solves for a more fluid workplace that can flex as needs change. Not only does this accelerate innovation and advance the culture of the organization, it can ensure real estate is always optimized.

4.	Balancing "we" and "me" work. Effective collaboration happens when there’s an ebb and flow of people coming together to work as a team and then moving apart to focus individually, process their ideas, and follow up on assigned tasks.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article.

Adapted from "4 Strategies for Building a Hybrid Workplace that Works," by Jim Keane and Todd Heiser. Illustration by Dominika Lipniewska.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 26, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says '4 Strategies for Building Hybrid Workplace that Works Focus on equity, engagement, and ease.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'OHBR WORKSPACES "By all indications the future of work is hybrid: 52% of U.S. workers would prefer a mix of working from home and the office, saying it has a positive impact on their ability to be creative, solve problems, and build relationships. Read the full article, "4 Strategies for Building a Hybrid Workplace that Works," by Jim Keane and Todd Heiser'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Research: Why Rejected Internal Candidates End Up Quitting And how to make it more likely that they'll stay. stay.'.

node.text:
Research indicates that rejected internal candidates are nearly two times as likely to leave their organizations compared to those who were either hired for an internal job or had not applied for a new job at all.

An analysis of just over 9,000 rejection experiences of employees at a Fortune 100 company points points to a couple reasons why.

🚪They didn't interview with the hiring manager. Internal candidates who were rejected after interviewing with the hiring manager were half as likely to exit as those rejected earlier in the process.

🚪They were passed over in favor of another internal candidate. A rejected candidate’s likelihood of leaving was cut in half if they were passed over in favor of an internal candidate rather than an external candidate.

Tap the link in our bio to learn about what companies can do about this.

Adapted from "Research: Why Rejected Internal Candidates End Up Quitting" by JR Keller and Kathryn Dlugos. Illustration by Monika Jurczyk.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Research: Why Rejected Internal Candidates End Up Quitting And how to make it more likely that they'll stay. stay.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 25, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR EMPLOYEE RETENTION No one wants to be turned down for a job, and the sting is often greater when you are told "no" by your current employer. Read the full article, "Research: Why Rejected Internal Candidates End Up Quitting," by JR Keller and Kathryn Dlugos'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR NETWORKING Rather than begrudgingly agreeing to meet someone or endlessly postponing social plans that you're less than enthusiastic about, know that there are alternatives. Read the full article, "How to Say No to 'Grabbing Coffee" by Jenny Taitz and Greg McKeown'.

node.text:
Sometimes it feels easier to say "yes" or postpone every invite — even when passing is what you really want.

The good news is that it’s possible to maintain your self-respect and your relationships even if you turn down an invitation. Here’s how.

☕ Pinpoint your values before requests arrive in your inbox. Instead of automatically scheduling when you get an invite, consider what feels essential this quarter — and beyond.

☕ Map out a budget — for your life. If you had one year left to live, how would you spend your time? Clear the way for what's most meaningful to you.

☕ Make it more effortless. Skip the insincere “Sure,” instead of kicking proposed plans down the line, and share your limits honestly.

Read more tips at the link in our bio.

Adapted from "How to Say No to “Grabbing Coffee” by Jenny Taitz and Greg McKeown.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Why Do So Many Strategies Fail? Too often, we ocus on the parts rather than the whole.'.

node.text:
These days, it’s not unusual for companies that have dominated their markets for decades to be blindsided by upstarts with radical new business models.

On the other hand, a lot of young ventures raise vast sums of money and attract tens of millions of customers, only to collapse when they can’t figure out how to fend off imitators.

In these situations and many others, the underlying cause is often a failure to take a holistic approach to strategy. Tap the link in our bio to read more about where strategies go wrong — and how to avoid the most common pitfalls.

Adapted from "Why Do So Many Strategies Fail?" by David J. Collis. Art credit: Ilan Rubin.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Why Do So Many Strategies Fail? Too often, we ocus on the parts rather than the whole.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR STRATEGY "Strategic adaptation must become an ongoing, iterative process of hypothesis, experimentation, learning, and action." Read the full article, "Why Do So Many Strategies Fail?," by David J. Collis'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 20, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'How Blockchain Can Help Combat Disinformation It's not a cure-all, but it does have the potential to address many of the risks and root causes.'.

node.text:
As digital disinformation grows more and more prevalent, there’s one emerging technology with the potential to address many of the root causes of and risks associated with misleading and manipulated media: blockchain. While it’s no panacea, blockchain can help in three key areas.

First, a blockchain-based system could offer a decentralized, trusted mechanism for verifying the provenance and other important metadata for online content.
Second, it could enable content creators and sharers to maintain a reputation independent of any publication or institution. A blockchain-based system can both verify the identity of a content creator and track their reputation for accuracy, essentially eliminating the need for a trusted, centralized institution.

And finally, it makes it possible to financially incentivize the creation and distribution of content that meets community-driven standards for accuracy and integrity.

Of course, any technological solution will have to be complemented by substantial policy and education initiatives. But in an increasingly complex digital media landscape, blockchain offers a promising starting point to ensure we can trust the information we see, hear, and watch.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article, "How Blockchain Can Help Combat Disinformation," by Kathryn Harrison and Amelia Leopold. Art credit: Illustration by Nata Schepy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 20, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'How Blockchain Can Help Combat Disinformation It's not a cure-all, but it does have the potential to address many of the risks and root causes.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR TECHNOLOGY "By providing greater transparency into the lifecycle of content, blockchain could offer a mechanism to restore trust in our digital ecosystem." Read the full article, "How Blockchain Can Help Combat Disinformation,' by Kathryn Harrison and Amelia Leopold'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'When Someone on Your Team Has Chronic Pain Up to 40% of Americans experience chronic pain- and that number will continue to increase.'.

node.text:
Up to 40% of American workers experience chronic pain — pain that persists for more than three months. This exceeds the number of people with cancer, diabetes, and heart disease combined.

It's often invisible — but it's associated with increased absence, decrements in job performance, concentration problems, physical limits, and displays of impatience toward coworkers and customers. The annual costs of chronic pain due to lost productivity have been estimated to be $216 billion in the United States.

An evidence-based model of prevention, intervention, and accommodation suggests these five strategies for managing employees with chronic conditions:

1️⃣ Be ready to support employees in chronic pain by listening. However, keep in mind that affected employees may avoid talking about their conditions due to fears of stigmatization, discrimination, or job loss. 

2️⃣ Focus on preventing work-related chronic pain. Paying careful attention to work conditions, and identifying and eliminating potential hazards, could prevent chronic pain for many workers even before it happens.

3️⃣ Design jobs with autonomy and skill variety. That way, employees can choose how and when they do work tasks depending on their ability at a given time. Working at a job that requires multiple skills can keep employees with chronic pain functional even when they are experiencing pain.

4️⃣ Allow flexible work. Chronic pain may mean that an individual can be more productive working from home or working flexible hours that accommodate their physical needs.

5️⃣ Increase access to chronic pain management resources in the organization. Besides generous benefits packages, resources such as pain support groups in the workplace or purchasing ergonomic furniture can make a big difference.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article.

Adapted from "When Someone on Your Team Has Chronic Pain," by Duygu Biricik Gulseren, Firat Sayin, E. Kevin Kelloway, and Nick Turner. Art credit: HBR Staff/Sidney Morgan/Stocksy/muuraa/Getty Images.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'When Someone on Your Team Has Chronic Pain Up to 40% of Americans experience chronic pain- and that number will continue to increase.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR MANAGING PEOPLE Chronic pain is an issue that affects both employees and companies. But how much do managers really know about the prevalence of chronic pain and how to help employees who experience it? Read the full article, "When Someone on Your Team Has Chronic Pain," by Duygu Biricik Gulseren et al.'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 18, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person and text that says 'End Imposter Syndrome In Your Workplace Seven strategies for leaders. 1'.

node.text:
Imposter syndrome largely blames women for not feeling confident enough — but it's workplaces that are making them feel this way. How can more companies create environments where imposter syndrome doesn't exist — and women are instead empowered to do their best work?

✔️ Address language. If someone on your team describes having feelings consistent with imposter syndrome, listen intently and share your own experiences of imposter syndrome. Highlight the conditions that triggered that response, such as chronic underrepresentation, uncredited work efforts, and microaggressions.

✔️ Reduce biases against women of color at work. Do what you can to help change how other people perceive their team members. For example, if a colleague warns of your team member’s contrarian approach in meetings, say something like, “Contrarian? I wouldn’t put it that way. I can always count on her to think deeper about our work and offer new insights and perspectives.”

✔️ Be data-driven. First, measure employee sentiment through anonymous feedback surveys, and accept feedback anytime. Assess the data not just by gender, but also by race and the intersection of gender, race, ethnicity, disability status, and other marginalized identities where possible. Second, assess your organization’s performance criteria and average time to promotion.

✔️ Set up accountability mechanisms for change. For example, evaluate all employees on how their work performance advances DEI-specific company goals. And make current and past demographic data publicly available, including measures on pay equity across race, sex, ability, and other key indicators.

Head to the link in our bio to learn more ways companies can start creating cultures where women don't feel like imposters.

Adapted from "End Imposter Syndrome in Your Workplace," by Ruchika Tulshyan and Jodi-Ann Burey. Art credit: Skizzomat/Marie Emmermann.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 18, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person and text that says 'End Imposter Syndrome In Your Workplace Seven strategies for leaders. 1'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR RACE & GENDER Let's stop calling natural, human tendencies of self-doubt, hesitation, and lack of confidence "imposter syndrome." Read the full article, "End Imposter Syndrome in Your Worklpace," by Ruchika Tulshyan and Jodi-Ann Burey'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What to Say (and What Not to Say) in a Difficult Conversation'.

node.text:
Even if you do your best to plan for a hard conversation, it's far too easy to offend or anger the other person.

“Don’t sweat the small stuff” is not great advice in these situations. You can get a lot of stuff right — your persuasive core arguments, your data and solutions, the setting and timing — and still see your intent derailed by small communication missteps. 

Swipe through ➡️ to learn some phrases to avoid in your next tough talk.

Tap the link in our bio for the full article.

Adapted from "Words and Phrases to Avoid in a Difficult Conversation," by Jim Detert. Illustration by Aron Vellekoop León.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What to Say (and What Not to Say) in a Difficult Conversation'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't assume your viewpoint is obvious. Avoid saying... Clearly... Obviously... Without a doubt...'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't exaggerate or generalize. Avoid saying... You always... You never...'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't Dontellotherswhatheyshoulddo. tell others what they should Try saying... You might consider... One possibility is... Have you ever thought of...'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't blame others for your feelings. Avoid saying... You make me feel nstead, try saying... When you do I feel'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Don't challenge someone's character or integrity. Avoid calling someone... Unprofessional Unethical'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Instead, explain how they're... Detracting from our mission. Not aligning with our values.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'And of course, never tell someone... It's not personal. Don't take this personally. Adaptec from "Words and Phrases to Avoid in a Difficult Conversation, by James R. Detert'.

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.
What’s a career crush? It’s a platonic crush you develop on someone who has a really cool job and is doing really cool things. In this episode, I interviewed one of my career crushes, Dave Jorgenson (@dave.jorgenson), to get to the bottom of what it’s like to be a full-time TikTok producer.

Dave's entire job is to make TikToks for the @washingtonpost. And his videos hit the mark — they're consistently informative, funny, and on-trend. I've always wondered: How does he do it? How does he continue to make hilarious, news-centered videos every day? What is it like to make TikToks for a living?

I sat down with Dave to chat with him about his journey from interning at The Colbert Report, to making YouTube videos, to becoming the newspaper-hat-wearing TikToker. We discussed his creative process, how he turned his job into one he loves, and how he helped The Washington Post’s TikTok reach almost one million followers.

I’m also really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend! Thanks for watching 🤗

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR STRATEGY "If the head of a rival firm has a distinctive name, he or she is more likely to make a move you haven't seen before." Read the full article, "CEOs with Unusual Names Pursue Unusual Strategies," by Amy Meeker'.

node.text:
An analysis of CEO names at 1,172 public firms showed that the more uncommon a CEO’s name was, the more the organization’s strategy deviated from industry norms. The researchers' conclusion? CEOs with uncommon names pursue unusual strategies.

Why? "Studies in psychology show that people with uncommon names are identified early on as being different from their peers," says David Zhu. "And because we develop our self-conception largely in relation to others, children viewed as outsiders in that way will internalize those perceptions and see themselves as different from other kids. That sticks with them into adulthood, and it seems that those who become CEOs often express their distinctiveness in the strategic choices they make."

In addition, children with uncommon names tend to be victims of teasing before they start their careers as adults. Many overcome those challenges — and those who become CEOs down the line may be more likely to try to stand out, according to Zhu.

The researchers controlled for numerous factors, including education, work experience, gender, firm size and performance, and characteristics of the board — and got the same results.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article.

Adapted from "CEOs with Unusual Names Pursue Unusual Strategies" by Amy Meeker.

node.text:
Women are often told that if they can fix their imposter syndrome, they'd be more successful in their careers. But is it really a lack of confidence holding them back — or is it systemic bias?

Today we spoke with @jodiannburey and @rtulshyan, HBR authors working to debunk the idea that imposter syndrome is a problem that's on individuals to solve. They argue that the “diagnosis” of imposter syndrome is problematic because it fails to acknowledge the historical and cultural contexts that affect the way women are treated — especially women of color.

Watch the full live conversation with HBR editor @ramsey.online here and add any questions you have about the topic in the comments.

Find the articles on HBR.org:

"Stop Telling Women They Have Imposter Syndrome"

"End Imposter Syndrome in Your Workplace"

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on July 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR CONFLICT Instead of instituting a ban on talking politics, build a culture that handles political differences in the workplace more productively. Û by Megan Reitz Read the article "Don't Ban 'Politics' at Work," and John Higgins'.

node.text:
Research shows that leaders are concerned that political discussions may become ungovernable or toxic, create workplace discord, or undermine productivity.

The result? Some organizations have banned such conversations altogether. But that has consequences. When Basecamp and Coinbase did it, many workers resigned.

Instead of instituting a ban, leaders should build cultures that handle political differences in the workplace more productively. Here's how to do that.

💬 Build empathy and respect for others’ views. Establish spaces where employees can learn informally about one another and find ways to negotiate their boundaries and differences. Political empathy and respect grow through the day-to-day sharing of personal stories and vulnerabilities.

💬 Accept mistakes gracefully. People stay silent because they fear being perceived negatively and upsetting or embarrassing the other person. But the more impassioned people are about something, the less articulate they become. Leaders in particular should ask themselves: How are employees received when they speak up but are inarticulate or unskilled in doing so?

💬 Teach people how to disagree. Developing the ability to disagree well has benefits beyond the company’s ability to handle political difference — it’s integral to the organization’s ability to innovate. Organizations must understand that disagreement turns destructive only when it is seen by one or both parties as an existential battle where “I’m right” and “You’re wrong.”

Adapted from "Don’t Ban “Politics” at Work," by Megan Reitz and John Higgins.
